data.name: Sleep Hygiene
data.description: From adjusting room temperature and reducing blue light exposure to setting boundaries around evening screen time, discover practical, research-backed tips to help you fall asleep faster and wake up feeling refreshed.
data.html:
Sleep Hygiene

Sleep is critical to overall health and wellbeing, impacting immune function, energy levels, mood, stress management, weight regulation, and brain function. But while many sources urge people to get seven to eight hours of sleep each night, far fewer offer practical guidance on how to actually make that happen. That’s where sleep hygiene comes in.

Sleep hygiene refers to the habits and environment that support consistent, restful sleep. Here are some foundational tips that can help you fall asleep more easily and wake up feeling refreshed.

Keep Your Room Cool, Dark, & Quiet

Temperature matters more than many realize. Research shows that the optimal sleep temperature is typically between 64 and 69 degrees Fahrenheit. If that feels too cold, try starting around 70 and slowly adjusting over time. Use breathable blankets and consider a fan if air conditioning isn't ideal.

Darkness is equally important. Melatonin, a hormone that regulates your sleep-wake cycle (or circadian rhythm), is released in response to darkness. Exposure to artificial light—especially in the evening—can suppress melatonin and make it harder to fall and stay asleep.

 

Limit Screen Exposure Before Bed

Screens emit blue light, which disrupts melatonin production. That includes phones, laptops, tablets, TVs, and even smartwatches. Beyond the light exposure, the content on these screens—like the news or social media—can also trigger stress, anxiety, or emotional stimulation that makes it harder to relax.

If cutting screen time isn’t realistic, here are a few workarounds:

  • Use blue light–blocking glasses
  • Try clip-on amber lenses if you already wear glasses
  • Switch to an e-reader that doesn’t emit light
  • Keep television viewing out of the bedroom

These can help reduce the impact of screens when used mindfully.

 

Set Boundaries Around Evening Content

What you consume—both visually and mentally—before bed affects sleep. Scrolling through negative news stories or intense social media discussions can lead to what's often called “doom scrolling,” which stimulates the nervous system and raises cortisol levels at a time when the body should be winding down.

Instead, try:

  • Reading a physical book
  • Journaling
  • Listening to calming music or a guided meditation

Choose evening habits that soothe rather than stimulate.

Improving sleep hygiene doesn’t require a complete life overhaul. Even small changes—like cooling your room a few degrees, limiting light exposure, or reducing evening screen time—can help your body shift into rest mode more naturally. Better sleep is not only possible, it’s essential.
